item.title: Treasuries Hold Gains in Countdown to 30-Year Sale: Markets Wrap
item.description: More evidence of cooling US inflation extended a week-long drop in bond yields, sent the dollar to a three-year low as stocks rose, signs traders are convinced the Federal Reserve has room to cut interest rates should the economic expansion lose steam.
item.dc:creator: Rita Nazareth

media:content.media:description: DoubleLine Group CEO Jeffrey Gundlach talks about the price of gold, fixed income, private credit, President Donald Trump's tax bill, Federal Reserve monetary policy and artificial intelligence with Lisa Abramowicz at the Bloomberg Global Credit Forum in Los Angeles.

item.title: Trump Floats Higher Auto Tariff, Guts California Gas-Car Ban
item.description: President Donald Trump said he may raise US auto tariffs in order to boost domestic auto manufacturing, a move that could further ratchet up tensions with trading partners.
item.dc:creator: Keith Laing, Mario Parker

media:content.media:description: Cars before loading onto a ship for export at the port in Lianyungang, Chin.

item.title: RBC’s Wilson Leaves Debt Syndication Desk for Toronto-Dominion
item.description: Daniel Wilson is leaving Royal Bank of Canada’s government debt syndication desk to join Toronto-Dominion Bank, according to people familiar with the matter who are not authorized to speak publicly.
item.dc:creator: Chunzi Xu

media:content.media:description: The Toronto-Dominion (TD) bank headquarters in the financial district of Toronto, Ontario, Canada, on Thursday, April 24, 2025. As President Donald Trump's trade war continues, Canadian equities are poised to outperform their US counterparts, portfolio managers argue.

item.title: S&P 500 Fluctuates After Trump Revives Unilateral Tariff Threats
item.description: The S&P 500 Index inched higher after shuffling between small gains and losses Thursday, with traders looking past another cooling inflation print and reacting little to the latest round of US-China trade talks.
item.dc:creator: Jess Menton

item.title: Trump Says US Government Will Get ‘Golden Share’ in US Steel
item.description: President Donald Trump said the US government will retain a “golden share” in United States Steel Corp. after its purchase by Japan’s Nippon Steel Corp.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove, Mario Parker

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump during a bill signing ceremony in the East Room of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, June 12, 2025. Trump is set to sign three congressional resolutions on Thursday that would bar California’s plan to end the sale of gasoline-only vehicles by 2035, Reuters reports, citing a White House official it did not identify.

item.title: Citi, Carlyle Partner Up to Lend And Invest in Fintech Startups
item.description: Citigroup Inc. and Carlyle Group Inc. are teaming up to provide debt and equity financing to growing financial technology firms, looking to take advantage of the booming asset-backed finance market.
item.dc:creator: Carmen Arroyo, Crystal Tse

item.title: Trump Calls for Fed Rate Cut, Says He Won’t Fire Powell
item.description: President Donald Trump suggests a two-point Fed rate cut and says he does not plan to fire Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell.

item.title: Oil Steadies as Traders Weigh Tariff Threats Against Iran Risk
item.description: Oil held steady as traders weighed renewed tariff threats from the US against the potential for widespread conflict in the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: Mia Gindis, Alex Longley

item.title: Pimco Sees ’Fragmentation Era’ in Annual Secular Outlook
item.description: Richard Clarida, global economic advisor at Pacific Investment Management Co. (Pimco), offers insight into the firm’s annual secular outlook with a focus on a “fragmenting” world, the long end of the yield curve, and the path forward for the Federal Reserve.

item.title: Asset Manager Dawson Pools Private Fund Stakes in $1.2 Billion Deal
item.description: Alternative asset manager Dawson Partners bundled up and sold private capital fund stakes as part of a $1.2 billion securitization, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Scott Carpenter

item.title: Ivanhoe Cuts Guidance as Restart Begins on Congo Copper Mine
item.description: Ivanhoe Mines Ltd. executives told investors on Thursday it’s too soon to provide output guidance for its massive copper mine in the Democratic Republic of Congo after seismic activity last month caused flooding deep underground.
item.dc:creator: Jacob Lorinc, James Attwood, Martin Ritchie

media:content.media:description: This April 26, 2018 general view shows the mining site of Kamoa Kakula, exploited by Kamoa Holding (Ivanhoe Mines, Zijin Mining Group, together with the DRC government), in Kamoa, 25km from Kolwezi. - The mining site is one of the largest unexploited copper field in the world, and stands on the site of the battles for Kolwezi, in May 1978 during the second Shaba War where French and Belgian paratroopers fought agains the Katanga rebels. On May 19, 1978, French soldiers parachuted into the Democratic Republic of Congo town of Kolwezi to rescue hundreds of Europeans held by rebels who had already massacred several. (Photo by CAROLINE THIRION / AFP) (Photo credit should read CAROLINE THIRION/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: European Pension Funds Risk Driving Sharp Dollar Sales, BNP Says
item.description: European pension funds have started to increase currency hedging and a continuation of this trend would amount to considerable US dollar selling, according to BNP Paribas SA strategists.
item.dc:creator: Alice Atkins

item.title: Corporate Insiders Use Rally to Dump Shares at Fastest Pace Since US Election
item.description: The US stock market is back on track and within spitting distance of February’s all-time highs. Yet corporate executives are dumping shares at the fastest clip since November.
item.dc:creator: Joel Leon

media:content.media:description: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange.

item.title: Cotton Declines as China Cuts Import View Amid Trade Tensions
item.description: Cotton futures dipped after China lowered its forecast for imports amid ongoing trade tensions with the US.
item.dc:creator: Ilena Peng, Dayanne Sousa

media:content.media:description: Workers tend to coffee plants at a plantation in Machado, Brazil.

item.title: UK Freezes 342 Properties Linked to Ex-Bangladesh Minister
item.description: British police have frozen 342 properties worth around £185 million ($252 million) linked to the family of Bangladesh’s ex-land minister, pursuing a crackdown on assets held by members of the former government.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Browning

media:content.media:description: Saifuzzaman Chowdhury at an event titled 'The Rise of Bengal Tiger: Trade and Investment Potentials in Bangladesh' in Manchester, UK, on Nov. 8, 2021.

item.title: Copper Clash Shows Cracks in Decades-Old Pricing System
item.description: Canadian miner Teck Resources Ltd. and Japan’s Sumitomo Metal Mining Co. are locked in a commercial dispute over a major copper supply deal, exposing cracks in a decades-old pricing system as the market endures a severe shortage.
item.dc:creator: Julian Luk, Archie Hunter

media:content.media:description: A worker heats copper in a smelter at a foundry.

item.title: Pirelli Top-Shareholder Sinochem Votes Against 2024 Results
item.description: Pirelli & C. SpA’s biggest shareholder, Sinochem International Corp., escalated a clash among the Italian tiremaker’s owners by voting against the approval of last year’s financial results.
item.dc:creator: Chiara Albanese

media:content.media:description: Pirelli tyres are pictured during the tests for the new Formula One Grand Prix season at the Circuit de Catalunya in Montmelo in the outskirts of Barcelona on February 20, 2019. (Photo by Josep LAGO / AFP) (Photo by JOSEP LAGO/AFP via Getty Images) Photographer: JOSEP LAGO/AFP

item.title: What the Price of Bananas Says About Inflation
item.description: Hello and welcome to the newsletter, a grab bag of daily content from the Odd Lots universe. Sometimes it's us, Joe Weisenthal and Tracy Alloway, bringing you our thoughts on the most recent developments in markets, finance and the economy. And sometimes it's contributions from our network of expert guests and sources. Whatever it is, we promise it will always be interesting.
item.dc:creator: Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

media:content.media:description: Italian visual artist Maurizio Cattelan's duct-taped Banana entitled "Comedian," is on display during a media preview at Sotheby's in New York, on November 8, 2024. A work by Belgian painter René Magritte, another by American Ed Ruscha and a vulgar banana are the stars that could set records for their authors in the art auctions that begin this week in New York in a market that hopes to overcome last year's slump. The two main houses Sotheby's and Christie's compete from November 18 with a rich offer in which the greatest exponents of 20th and 21st century painting abound, such as Picasso, Magritte, Matisse, Miró, Kankinsky, Moore, Ruscha, Basquiat, Carrington, Rothko, Lichtenstein, Giacometti or Haring. (Photo by kena betancur / AFP) / RESTRICTED TO EDITORIAL USE - MANDATORY MENTION OF THE ARTIST UPON PUBLICATION - TO ILLUSTRATE THE EVENT AS SPECIFIED IN THE CAPTION / TO GO WITH AFP STORY BY Ana FERNANDEZ: "Magritte, Rucha and... a banana, in a bid to set new records at New York auctions" (Photo by KENA BETANCUR/AFP via Getty Images) Photographer: KENA BETANCUR/AFP

item.title: Over 200 Dead After London-Bound Boeing Jet Crashes in India
item.description: More than 200 people have been found dead at the crash site of a Boeing Co. 787 Dreamliner operated by Air India that was bound for London, according to police officials. Flight AI171 crashed shortly after taking off in Ahmedabad in the worst accident involving the US planemaker’s most advanced twin-aisle aircraft. Officials didn’t immediately say how many of those people were passengers, crew or area residents. Flight AI171 was carrying 242 passengers and crew. Video footage shared on social media showed a giant plume of smoke engulfing the crash site. “We have found 204 bodies, we are looking for more bodies,” Police Commissioner G.S. Malik told Bloomberg. “There is a chance that there may be survivors. 41 injured are being treated. These include people who were staying in the residential area.” (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Reliance Industries Sells $900 Million Stake in Asian Paints
item.description: Reliance Industries Ltd. divested about 3.7% stake in Asian Paints Ltd. by selling shares in a block trade, raising 77 billion rupees ($900 million), according to an exchange filing on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Ashutosh Joshi

media:content.media:description: Buckets of Asian Paints Ltd. paint at a store in Mumbai, India, on Saturday, Feb 6, 2021. India's central bank kept interest rates on hold Friday and began withdrawing some pandemic-era policies, while reiterating its intent to keep its stance accommodative to support economic growth.

item.title: Private Equity Stuck in Limbo Gets Assist From Direct Lenders
item.description: As private equity firms struggle to sell the companies they own and return cash to investors, their counterparts in the world of private credit are offering special loans to tide them over.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Schneider, Olivia Fishlow

item.title: China Sees First Private Builder Dollar-Bond Sale Since 2023
item.description: Seazen Group Ltd. sold a $300 million note Thursday, the first dollar-bond issuance in more than two years by a major private-sector Chinese developer.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Cai, Ameya Karve, Qingqi She, Emma Dong

item.title: Egypt Makes LNG Supply Deals With Aramco, Trafigura and Shell
item.description: Egypt agreed to buy liquefied natural gas over 2 1/2 years from suppliers including Saudi Aramco, Trafigura Group and Vitol Group, putting the country on course to be a long-term importer as local production slows.
item.dc:creator: Salma El Wardany, Stephen Stapczynski, Anna Shiryaevskaya, Ruth Liao

media:content.media:description: The Cairo West power plant in Egypt.

item.title: BlackRock Has Built an AI Analyst, ‘Asimov,’ to Scan Filings
item.description: BlackRock Inc. is planning for artificial intelligence to have a much bigger role in investing.
item.dc:creator: Silla Brush

media:content.media:description: The Blackrock headquarters in New York

item.title: Dollar Falls to Lowest Since 2022 as Economic Outlook Dims
item.description: The dollar fell to the weakest level in three years amid worries over US tariffs and the outlook for the US economy.
item.dc:creator: Anya Andrianova, Vassilis Karamanis

item.title: Goldman’s Rosner: No Need to Go Into the 30-Year Bond
item.description: Lindsay Rosner, head of multi-sector investing at Goldman Sachs Asset Management, discusses the yield curve ahead of Thursday’s 30-year US Treasury auction.

item.title: Gold Advances on Fed Rate-Cut Bets and Middle East Tensions
item.description: Gold rose after another soft inflation report bolstered bets that the Federal Reserve may need to cut interest rates later this year.
item.dc:creator: Yvonne Yue Li, Jack Ryan

media:content.media:description: Gold bars at the Italpreziosi SpA precious metals refinery plant arranged in Arezzo, Italy, on Tuesday, May 6, 2025. Gold fell, snapping a two-day advance, as signs of progress on US-China trade talks curbed demand for havens even as military hostilities between India and Pakistan escalated. Photographer: Alessia Pierdomenico/Bloomberg

item.title: CoreWeave Shorts Face 150% Borrow Costs After $1.6 Billion Loss
item.description: CoreWeave Inc.’s soaring share price is torching short sellers who are paying high prices to bet that the stock will soon fall back to earth.
item.dc:creator: Carmen Reinicke

item.title: Cathie Wood Says Trump Era Is Reviving Corporate Risk Appetite
item.description: Corporate America is regaining its appetite for risk as expectations build around Donald Trump’s push for deregulation and tax cuts, according to ARK Investment Management founder Cathie Wood.
item.dc:creator: Justina Lee

media:content.media:description: CEO of Ark Investment Management Cathie Wood

item.title: Ecuador Bonds Return 41% on Hopes of End to Political Turmoil
item.description: Optimism that Ecuador is finally exiting years of political chaos and economic stagnation under the recently re-elected President Daniel Noboa sent its bonds to a three-year high, even as the country remains mired in violence.
item.dc:creator: Zijia Song
